The Power of Bias: Optimizing Client Selection in Federated Learning with Heterogeneous Differential Privacy

Jiating Ma, Yipeng Zhou,  Qi Li,  Quan Z. Sheng,  Laizhong Cui,  Jiangchuan Liu Jiating Ma and Laizhong Cui are with the College of Computer Science and Software Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, China, and also with the Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy (SZ), Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, China (E-mail: 1270901086@qq.com, cuilz@szu.edu.cn).Yipeng Zhou and Quan Z. Sheng are with the School of Computing, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Macquarie University, Macquarie Park, NSW 2119, Australia (E-mail: yipeng.zhou@mq.edu.au, michael.sheng@mq.edu.au).Qi Li is with the Institute for Network Sciences and Cyberspace, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100190, China, and also with the Beijing National Research Center for Information Science and Technology, Beijing 100190, China (E-mail: qli01@tsinghua.edu.cn).Jiangchuan Liu is with the School of Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC V5A 1S6, Canada (E-mail: jcliu@cs.sfu.ca).The corresponding author is Laizhong Cui.
Abstract

To preserve the data privacy, the federated learning (FL) paradigm emerges in which clients only expose model gradients rather than original data for conducting model training. To enhance the protection of model gradients in FL, differentially private federated learning (DPFL) is proposed which incorporates differentially private (DP) noises to obfuscate gradients before they are exposed. Yet, an essential but largely overlooked problem in DPFL is the heterogeneity of clients’ privacy requirement, which can vary significantly between clients and extremely complicates the client selection problem in DPFL. In other words, both the data quality and the influence of DP noises should be taken into account when selecting clients. To address this problem, we conduct convergence analysis of DPFL under heterogeneous privacy, a generic client selection strategy, popular DP mechanisms and convex loss. Based on convergence analysis, we formulate the client selection problem to minimize the value of loss function in DPFL with heterogeneous privacy, which is a convex optimization problem and can be solved efficiently. Accordingly, we propose the DPFL-BCS (biased client selection) algorithm. The extensive experiment results with real datasets under both convex and non-convex loss functions indicate that DPFL-BCS can remarkably improve model utility compared with the SOTA baselines.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, differentially private, biased client selection, convergence rate.

I Introduction

Artificial intelligence empowered by machine learning has achieved an unprecedented success. However, the advancement of machine learning gives rise to concerns on data privacy infringement because training complex machine learning models heavily relies on data extensively collected from clients [1]. As reported in [2], user privacy can be easily inferred from collected data. To preserve data privacy during model training, the federated learning (FL) paradigm emerges, in which clients only exchange their model gradients rather than original data with a parameter server (PS) for multiple global iterations to complete model training [3].

However, exposing model gradients is still susceptible to malicious attacks. As investigated in [4], if model gradients are excessively exposed to attackers, FL clients may suffer from membership inference attacks [5] and reconstruction attacks [6]. To defend against these attacks, differentially private federated learning (DPFL) is proposed which injects noises generated by differentially private (DP) mechanisms to distort gradients before their exposure. Although DP noises can protect clients from external attackers, the biggest challenge of DPFL lies in significantly compromised model utility due to the disturbance of DP noises. According to [7, 8], model accuracy can be lowered by more than 40% by straightly injecting DP noises, making intelligent services useless. Significant efforts have been dedicated to improving DPFL model utility from various perspectives, such as adaptively allocating noises for each iteration [9], probabilistically exposing large magnitude gradients for each iteration [10, 7], optimizing the number of total exposure times [11] and designing a personalized data transformation[12].

It is worth noting that the privacy requirements among clients are inherently heterogeneous in all aforementioned works, in which clients can set noise scales according to their own requirement, e.g., [8, 13, 14]. Unfortunately, none of these works take this privacy heterogeneity into account when optimizing DPFL. According to [15], the privacy requirement heterogeneity is rooted from the following fact. An altruistic and cooperative client inclines to add small noises, while a selfish and conservative client inclines to add large noises. Thereby, it is likely that noise scales of different clients have a giant discrepancy. Currently, there exists very limited works discussing the importance of this problem but only attempting to solve it from a heuristic perspective. Aldaghri et al. [14] studied the heterogeneous differential privacy in federated linear regression and proposed to tune aggregation weights of clients based on their privacy budgets. Liu et al. [8] proposed to extract the top singular subspace of the model updates uploaded by clients with more privacy budgets to project model updates from clients with small privacy budgets before the PS aggregates them. Due to their heuristic design, these works without theoretical guarantees are probably far away from the optimal solution.

To address the challenge, we optimize the strategy to select clients in DPFL according to heterogeneous privacy requirements among clients with theoretical guarantees. Intuitively speaking, a dedicatedly designed client selection strategy should select clients with small noises more frequently and vice verse in case that DPFL performance is impaired by large noises. Inspired by this intuition, we propose a biased client selection framework for DPFL (which is more generic than unbiased client selection widely adopted in previous works [8, 11]) so that client selection can be flexibly adjusted in accordance with heterogeneous differential privacy among FL clients. Then, convergence analysis of DPFL is conducted to quantify the influence of heterogeneous differential privacy and biased client selection on model utility under standard DP mechanisms (i.e., Gaussian [16] and Laplace mechanisms [17]) and convex loss. Based on convergence analysis, we formulate the problem to minimize the loss function with respect to the selection probability of each client. We prove that this is a convex optimization problem and further explore how to solve this problem efficiently and accurately in practical systems. Inspired by our analysis, the DPFL-BCS (biased client selection) algorithm is designed, which can be deployed on a semi-honest-but-curious PS [18].

In summary, our work contributes to optimizing FL model utility while satisfying heterogeneous privacy requirements on clients. More specifically, our contribution is four-folds:

  • •

    By proposing a generic client selection framework, we theoretically derive the convergence rate of DPFL, in which DP noises are injected to distort gradients according to clients’ heterogeneous privacy requirements.

  • •

    Based on our convergence analysis, we formulate a convex optimization problem to minimize the convergence loss (equivalent to maximizing model utility) under heterogeneous privacy requirement. By solving the problem, we devise the DPFL-BCS algorithm that can optimally select participating clients.

  • •

    We explore how to implement DPFL-BCS efficiently in practical systems by exploring methods to estimate problem-related parameters (which are essential for optimizing client selection) without incurring additional privacy loss.

  • •

    To demonstrate the superiority of DPFL-BCS, we conduct extensive experiments with real datasets, i.e., Lending Club [17], MNIST [19], Fashion-MNIST [7], FEMNIST[20] and CIFAR-10 [21], under both convex and non-convex loss functions. The experimental results show that DPFL-BCS can remarkably improve model utility in comparison with the SOTA baselines. In particular, model accuracy can be incredibly improved by 30∼similar-to\sim40% under extremely heterogeneous privacy requirement.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The preliminary knowledge of DP and our problem definition are introduced in Sec. II. Sec. III encompasses the description of the DPFL framework and the derivation of convergence. Next, the design of DPFL-BCS algorithm to optimize the client selection strategy is proposed in Sec. IV. Sec. V reports our experiment results and the relevant works are discussed in Sec. VI. Finally, we conclude our work in Sec. VII.

II Preliminary and Problem Statement

In this section, we introduce the preliminary knowledge of DP and define the problem studied by our work.

II-A Preliminary of Differential Privacy

Let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} denotes a DP mechanism, which actually is a randomized algorithm. ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfying the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP can be formally defined as:

Definition 1.

((ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-Differential Privacy [22]). P​r​{ℳ​(𝒟)∈𝒮}≤exp⁡(ϵ)×P​r​{ℳ​(𝒟′)∈𝒮}+δ.𝑃𝑟ℳ𝒟𝒮italic-ϵ𝑃𝑟ℳsuperscript𝒟′𝒮𝛿\displaystyle{Pr}\{\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{S}\}\leq\exp{(\epsilon)}\times{Pr}\{\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}\}+\delta. (1)

Here, Range(ℳ)ℳ(\mathcal{M}) is the output range of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}.

Here, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) is the privacy budget, depicting the amount of privacy loss of a single query. FL clients can set (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) according to their own privacy requirement, resulting in heterogeneous privacy.

Our study is based on two most popular DP mechanisms: Gaussian Mechanism (GM) and Laplace Mechanism (LM). II-B Problem Statement

We consider a generic DPFL system with a parameter server (PS) and N𝑁N clients denoted by 𝒩={1,⋯,N}𝒩1⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,\cdots,N\}. Similar to existing DPFL works [8, 18], our study is based on a semi-honest-but-curious PS, which satisfies following properties: (1) the PS selects clients honestly according to the client selection strategy; (2) the PS honestly aggregates model gradients collected from the selected clients; (3) the PS does not modify/destroy any information for aggregation; (4) the PS tries to derive sensitive information from received model gradients and loss values of trained models. Let (ϵn,δn)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛(\epsilon_{n},\delta_{n}) and Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} denote the privacy budget of client n𝑛n and the number of times client n𝑛n participates in FL, respectively. Each client n𝑛n owns a private local dataset denoted by 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} with cardinality Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n}. The objective of these clients is to collaboratively minimize the global loss function F​(𝐰)=1N​∑n∈𝒩Fn​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰1𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰F(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}F_{n}(\mathbf{w}). Here, Fn​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰F_{n}(\mathbf{w}) is the local loss function (or objective) of client n𝑛n defined as Fn​(𝐰)=1Dn​∑ζ∈𝒟nfn​(𝐰,ζ)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰1subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝜁subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛𝐰𝜁F_{n}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{D_{n}}\sum_{\zeta\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}f_{n}(\mathbf{w},\zeta). 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} represent model parameters to be learned with dimension d𝑑d and ζ𝜁\zeta represents a particular data sample.

In FL, rather than exposing 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n}, each client only returns gradients 𝐠ntsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t} to the PS for multiple global iterations via Internet communications. However, during model communications, malicious attackers can easily eavesdrop model gradients uploaded from clients [23], who can then put off membership inference [5] or reconstruction attacks [6] towards FL clients.

To defend against attackers, DPFL resorts to injecting DP noises to distort gradients before their uploading. DPFL regards global model parameters of the last global iteration, i.e., 𝐰t−1superscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}^{t-1} in global iteration t𝑡t, as query input and model gradients obtained by local training as query results, which should be distorted by noises. Thus, client n𝑛n if selected will return 𝐠^nt=𝐠nt+𝐙ntsuperscriptsubscript^𝐠𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐙𝑛𝑡\mathbf{\hat{g}}_{n}^{t}=\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}+\mathbf{Z}_{n}^{t} to the PS, where 𝐙ntsuperscriptsubscript𝐙𝑛𝑡\mathbf{Z}_{n}^{t} represent DP noises on client n𝑛n in global iteration t𝑡t. In most existing DPFL works [8, 11], clients are selected in a pure random manner.

An Illustrative Example. To explain the shortcoming of these works, we show a concrete example in Fig. 1. There are three clients with heterogeneous data samples and distinct privacy requirements. In this example, the noise scale is small on Client 1, but is much bigger on Clients 2 and 3. From the data distribution perspective, Client 3 owns the most number of samples while the data distribution of Client 2 is closest to the distribution of all data among all clients which is called IID. In this example, a random client selection strategy cannot discriminate values of different clients suggesting that we should at least consider: 1) The noise scale, e.g., the smallest noise scale on Client 1 will reduce the disturbance of noise; 2) The number of data samples, e.g., Client 3 owns the most number of data samples, which is vital to FL; 3) The data sample distribution, e.g., the IID data distribution on Client 2 is favored for the convergence of FL. This example indicates that client selection is non-trivial in DPFL with heterogeneous privacy. It is subject to both the noise scale and the data quality. The problem will be much more complicated when considering the entire FL process with multiple rounds.

Formal Problem Definition. Suppose that K𝐾K clients can be selected by PS to participate in FL per global iteration. In most existing works [11, 8], it is common to implement an unbiased strategy to randomly select clients with Tn=K​TNsubscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇𝑁T_{n}=\frac{KT}{N}, where T𝑇T is the total number of global iterations. This trivial strategy can guarantee the convergence of FL without DP [24]. However, we will theoretically prove that this simple selection strategy fails to attain satisfactory model utility by ignoring the impact of heterogeneous privacy.

In our study, we discuss a more general scenario by only setting Tn∈ℕsubscript𝑇𝑛ℕT_{n}\in\mathbb{N} and ∑n∈𝒩Tn=K​Tsubscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}=KT. Here, Tn,∀n∈𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, are the most crucial variables to be optimized by our work.

III Convergence Analysis with Heterogeneous Privacy

In this section, we propose a generic DPFL framework with a biased client selection strategy so that we can analyze the convergence of DPFL under biased client selection. A summary of the key notations is presented in Appendix A.

III-A DPFL Framework

Biased client selection is not adopted in most previous DPFL works because biased selection can lower model utility [25]. Yet, as we have discussed in the last section, unbiased client selection may also result in inferior learning performance with heterogeneous privacy. To explore this point, we expand the client selection strategy space by including all sequences of T1,…,TNsubscript𝑇1…subscript𝑇𝑁T_{1},\dots,T_{N} satisfying Tn∈ℕsubscript𝑇𝑛ℕT_{n}\in\mathbb{N} and ∑n∈𝒩Tn=K​Tsubscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}=KT. Let pn=TnK​Tsubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇p_{n}=\frac{T_{n}}{KT} denotes the selection probability of client n𝑛n. Corresponding to the huge space, we describe the DPFL framework using a generic client selection strategy as follows:

  1. 1.

    Each client sets its privacy budget (ϵn,δn)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛(\epsilon_{n},\delta_{n}). The PS initializes the global model 𝐰^0superscript^𝐰0\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{0} and allocates the selection probability for each client n𝑛n, i.e., pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}, subject to ∑n∈𝒩pn=1subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑝𝑛1\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}p_{n}=1. Based on pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}, client n𝑛n sets the privacy budget consumed per global iteration if selected as ϵnl=ϵnpn​K​Tsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑙subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛𝐾𝑇\epsilon_{n}^{l}=\frac{\epsilon_{n}}{p_{n}KT} and δnl=δnpn​K​Tsuperscriptsubscript𝛿𝑛𝑙subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛𝐾𝑇\delta_{n}^{l}=\frac{\delta_{n}}{p_{n}KT}.

  2. 2.

    At the beginning of each iteration t∈[1,T]𝑡1𝑇t\in[1,T], the PS selects K𝐾K participating clients based on pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}, denoted by 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t}. Then, the PS distributes the global model 𝐰^t−1superscript^𝐰𝑡1\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1} to selected clients.

  3. 3.

    Each selected client, e.g., n∈𝒮t𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}, conducts a round of local iteration with its private dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} to update 𝐰nt←𝐰^t−1−𝐠nt←superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑡superscript^𝐰𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡{\mathbf{w}}_{n}^{t}\leftarrow\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1}-\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}. Here 𝐠nt=ηt​∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,𝒟n)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑛\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}=\eta_{t}\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\mathcal{D}_{n}) denote gradients and ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is learning rate. Gradients are then distorted by 𝐠^nt=𝐠nt+𝐙ntsubscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐙𝑛𝑡\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}=\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}+\mathbf{Z}_{n}^{t}, where the noise terms 𝐙ntsuperscriptsubscript𝐙𝑛𝑡\mathbf{Z}_{n}^{t} are determined by (ϵnlsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑙\epsilon_{n}^{l}, δnlsuperscriptsubscript𝛿𝑛𝑙\delta_{n}^{l}) and the DP mechanisms. 𝐠^ntsubscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n} are returned to the PS for aggregation and client n𝑛n updates its participation times as Cn=Cn+1subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛1C_{n}=C_{n}+1. When Cn≥pn​K​Tsubscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛𝐾𝑇C_{n}\geq p_{n}KT, client n𝑛n will not participate anymore.

  4. 4.

    The PS aggregates returned noisy gradients to update the global model as 𝐰^t←𝐰^t−1−1K​∑n∈𝒮t𝐠^nt.←superscript^𝐰𝑡superscript^𝐰𝑡11𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t}\leftarrow{\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1}-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{n\in{\mathcal{S}_{t}}}\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}}. After gradient aggregation, the PS goes back to Step 2) to kick off a new round of global iteration with 𝐰^tsuperscript^𝐰𝑡\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t}.

Remarks. The biased client selection strategy can be interpreted as follows. According to the aggregation rule on the PS, the expectation of aggregated gradients over K𝐾K selected clients is 𝔼​[1K​∑n∈𝒮t𝐠^nt]=1K∗K∗∑n∈𝒩pn​𝐠^nt=∑n∈𝒩TnK​T​𝐠^nt𝔼delimited-[]1𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛1𝐾𝐾subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇subscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}]=\frac{1}{K}*K*\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}p_{n}\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{T_{n}}{KT}\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}. An unbiased strategy should set Tn=K​TNsubscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇𝑁T_{n}=\frac{KT}{N} to guarantee 𝔼​[1K​∑n∈𝒮t𝐠^nt]=1N​∑n∈𝒩𝐠^nt𝔼delimited-[]1𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩subscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}]=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n}. This insight is correct in FL without DP, and has been widely adopted in prior works [24, 26]. In DPFL, our study will reveal a counter-intuitive conclusion that a biased setting of Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} can make model utility better if privacy is heterogeneous because Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} will affect privacy consumption, and thus setting the value of Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} should take the privacy budget into account.

III-B Convergence Analysis of DPFL

To quantify the influence of different client selection strategies and heterogeneous noise scales on FL model utility, we derive the convergence of DPFL without specifying the values of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} or Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}.

Before we derive the convergence rate, the influence of DP noises is quantified by their variances. Two most popular DP mechanisms, i.e., Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms, are analyzed in our work. Let 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} and 𝒟n′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛′\mathcal{D}_{n}^{\prime} represent two adjacent datasets. Gradients obtained by client n𝑛n in global iteration t𝑡t on 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} and 𝒟n′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛′\mathcal{D}_{n}^{\prime} are denoted by 𝐠nt=ηt​∇F​(𝐰nt−1,𝒟n)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑛\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}=\eta_{t}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{n}^{t-1},\mathcal{D}_{n}) and 𝐠nt′=ηt​∇F​(𝐰nt−1,𝒟n′)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛superscript𝑡′subscript𝜂𝑡∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛′\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t^{\prime}}=\eta_{t}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{n}^{t-1},\mathcal{D}_{n}^{\prime}), respectively. Then, the variances of DP noises can be represented by the following lemmas.

Lemma 1.

(Variance of Gaussian Mechanism [16]) Let ΞG:=max∀𝐰,∀n,∀ζ∈𝒟n⁡‖∇Fn​(𝐰,ζ)‖2<∞assignsubscriptΞ𝐺subscriptfor-all𝐰for-all𝑛for-all𝜁subscript𝒟𝑛subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰𝜁2\Xi_{G}:=\max_{\forall\mathbf{w},\forall n,\forall\zeta\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w},\zeta)\|_{2}<\infty denotes the L​2𝐿2L2 magnitude bound of gradients and ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} denotes the learning rate. Suppose that client n𝑛n is selected to participate in the t𝑡t-th global iteration, its L​2𝐿2L2-sensitivity is Δ​𝐠n,G=2​ηt​ΞGDnΔsubscript𝐠𝑛𝐺2subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΞ𝐺subscript𝐷𝑛\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n,G}=\frac{2\eta_{t}\Xi_{G}}{D_{n}}. Let 𝐙n,Gtsubscriptsuperscript𝐙𝑡𝑛𝐺\mathbf{Z}^{t}_{n,G} denote Gaussian noises added to 𝐠ntsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}. The variance of 𝐙n,Gtsubscriptsuperscript𝐙𝑡𝑛𝐺\mathbf{Z}^{t}_{n,G} is 𝔼​[‖𝐙n,Gt‖2]=4​ηt2​ΞG2​d​c22​Tn​ln⁡(1/δn)Dn2​ϵn2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐙𝑡𝑛𝐺24superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2superscriptsubscriptΞ𝐺2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑐22subscript𝑇𝑛1subscript𝛿𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{Z}^{t}_{n,G}\|^{2}]=\frac{4\eta_{t}^{2}\Xi_{G}^{2}dc_{2}^{2}T_{n}\ln(1/\delta_{n})}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}}.

Lemma 1 can be proved based on [16]. For client n𝑛n, it is easy to obtain its L​2𝐿2L2-sensitivity in the t𝑡t-th global iteration as ‖𝐠nt−𝐠nt′‖2=ηtDn​‖∑ζ∈𝒟n∇Fn​(𝐰t−1,ζ)−∑ζ′∈𝒟n′∇Fn​(𝐰t−1,ζ′)‖2≤2​ηt​ΞGDnsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛superscript𝑡′2subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐷𝑛subscriptnormsubscript𝜁subscript𝒟𝑛∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript𝐰𝑡1𝜁subscriptsuperscript𝜁′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛′∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝜁′22subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΞ𝐺subscript𝐷𝑛\|\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t}-\mathbf{g}_{n}^{t^{\prime}}\|_{2}=\frac{\eta_{t}}{D_{n}}\|\sum_{\zeta\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{t-1},\zeta)-\sum_{\zeta^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D}_{n}^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{t-1},\zeta^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq\frac{2\eta_{t}\Xi_{G}}{D_{n}}. Then, the variance of 𝐙n,Gtsubscriptsuperscript𝐙𝑡𝑛𝐺\mathbf{Z}^{t}_{n,G} can be derived by substituting the sensitivity Δ​𝐠n,G=2​ηt​ΞGDnΔsubscript𝐠𝑛𝐺2subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΞ𝐺subscript𝐷𝑛\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n,G}=\frac{2\eta_{t}\Xi_{G}}{D_{n}} into Theorem 1 in [16].

Lemma 2.

(Variance of Laplace Mechanism [11]) Let ΞL:=max∀𝐰,∀n,∀ζ∈𝒟n⁡‖∇Fn​(𝐰,ζ)‖1<∞assignsubscriptΞ𝐿subscriptfor-all𝐰for-all𝑛for-all𝜁subscript𝒟𝑛subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰𝜁1\Xi_{L}:=\max_{\forall\mathbf{w},\forall n,\forall\zeta\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w},\zeta)\|_{1}<\infty denotes the L​1𝐿1L1 magnitude bound of gradients and ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} denotes the learning rate. Suppose that client n𝑛n is selected to participate in the t𝑡t-th global iteration, its L​1𝐿1L1-sensitivity of 𝐠ntsubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡𝑛\mathbf{g}^{t}_{n} is Δ​𝐠n,L=2​ηt​ΞLDnΔsubscript𝐠𝑛𝐿2subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΞ𝐿subscript𝐷𝑛\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n,L}=\frac{2\eta_{t}\Xi_{L}}{D_{n}}. To simplify our discussion, we unify the presentation of the sensitivity of 𝐠ntsubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡𝑛\mathbf{g}^{t}_{n} and the noise terms according to Lemmas 1 and 2. Let Δ​𝐠nΔsubscript𝐠𝑛\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n} and 𝐙ntsubscriptsuperscript𝐙𝑡𝑛\mathbf{Z}^{t}_{n} denote the sensitivity of 𝐠ntsubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡𝑛\mathbf{g}^{t}_{n} and the noise terms regardless of the DP mechanism, respectively. The variance of the noise terms is denoted as 𝔼​[‖𝐙nt‖2]=Λ​ηt2​Tnz​Φn𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐙𝑡𝑛2Λsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧subscriptΦ𝑛\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{Z}^{t}_{n}\|^{2}]=\Lambda\eta_{t}^{2}T_{n}^{z}\Phi_{n}, where Λ=4​ΞG2​d​c22Λ4superscriptsubscriptΞ𝐺2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑐22\Lambda=4\Xi_{G}^{2}dc_{2}^{2}, z=1𝑧1z=1, Φn=ln⁡(1/δn)Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1subscript𝛿𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{n})}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for GM and Λ=8​d​ΞL2Λ8𝑑superscriptsubscriptΞ𝐿2\Lambda=8d\Xi_{L}^{2}, z=2𝑧2z=2, Φn=1Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{1}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for LM.

Similar to prior works [27, 11, 24, 28], we make following assumptions to analyze the convergence of DPFL under convex loss.

Assumption 1.

Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} is L-smooth: for all 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, Fn​(𝐯)≤Fn​(𝐰)+(𝐯−𝐰)T​∇Fn​(𝐰)+L2​‖𝐯−𝐰‖2subscript𝐹𝑛𝐯subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰superscript𝐯𝐰𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰𝐿2superscriptnorm𝐯𝐰2F_{n}(\mathbf{v})\leq F_{n}(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{L}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|^{2}, ∀nfor-all𝑛\forall n.

Assumption 2.

Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex: for all 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, Fn​(𝐯)≥Fn​(𝐰)+(𝐯−𝐰)T​∇Fn​(𝐰)+μ2​‖𝐯−𝐰‖2subscript𝐹𝑛𝐯subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰superscript𝐯𝐰𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰𝜇2superscriptnorm𝐯𝐰2F_{n}(\mathbf{v})\geq F_{n}(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|^{2}, ∀nfor-all𝑛\forall n.

Assumption 3.

The variance of stochastic gradients in each client is bounded: 𝔼​‖∇Fn​(𝐰,𝒟n)−∇Fn​(𝐰)‖2≤σ2𝔼superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰subscript𝒟𝑛∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{n})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}, ∀nfor-all𝑛\forall n.

Similar to [27], to analyze the influence of selection bias, we define selection skew to quantify the difference between a biased selection strategy and the random selection strategy.

Definition 2.

(Selection skew [27]). For any model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and any sequence of Tn,∀n∈𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, we define

ρ​(𝐰,T1,⋯,TN)=∑n∈𝒩TnK​T​[Fn​(𝐰)−Fn∗]F​(𝐰)−1N​∑n∈𝒩Fn∗.𝜌𝐰subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛𝐹𝐰1𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑛\displaystyle\rho(\mathbf{w},T_{1},\cdots,T_{N})=\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{T_{n}}{KT}[F_{n}(\mathbf{w})-F_{n}^{*}]}{F(\mathbf{w})-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}F^{*}_{n}}. (2)
Definition 3.

(Lower bound of selection skew [27]). For any model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and any sequence of Tn,∀n∈𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, we define

ρm​i​n≜min𝐰,T1,⋯,TNρ​(𝐰,T1,⋯,TN).≜subscript𝜌𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝐰subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁𝜌𝐰subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁\displaystyle\rho_{min}\triangleq\mathop{\min}_{\mathbf{w},T_{1},\cdots,T_{N}}\rho(\mathbf{w},T_{1},\cdots,T_{N}). (3)

In FL, the data distribution among clients is non-IID. The non-IID degree for each client n𝑛n can be quantified by the difference of loss achieved by global optimal model and local optimal model, which is Γn=Fn​(𝐰∗)−Fn∗subscriptΓ𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛superscript𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛\Gamma_{n}=F_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*})-F_{n}^{*}. Here 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} and Fn∗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}^{*} represent global optimal model and minimum local loss, respectively. The convergence of DPFL is presented as follows.

Theorem 5.

(Convergence with Decaying Learning Rate). Let Assumptions 1-3 hold. Let learning rate ηt=2μ​(t+γ)subscript𝜂𝑡2𝜇𝑡𝛾\eta_{t}=\frac{2}{\mu(t+\gamma)} and γ=8​Lμ𝛾8𝐿𝜇\gamma=\frac{8L}{\mu}. Given a selection strategy (defined by Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}), the convergence of the DPFL framework after T𝑇T global iterations is:

𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)]−F∗≤1γ+T​L​γ2​‖𝐰^0−𝐰∗‖2+1γ+T​4​L​σ2μ2​K𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹1𝛾𝑇𝐿𝛾2superscriptnormsuperscript^𝐰0superscript𝐰21𝛾𝑇4𝐿superscript𝜎2superscript𝜇2𝐾\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{T})]-F^{*}\leq\frac{1}{\gamma+T}\frac{L\gamma}{2}\|\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}+\frac{1}{\gamma+T}\frac{4L\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}K}
+\displaystyle+ 1(γ+T)​T​4​L2K​μ2​∑n∈𝒩Tn​Γn⏟Non-IID+3​L2​μ​∑n∈𝒩(TnK​T−ρm​i​nN)​Γn⏟Biased Selectionsubscript⏟1𝛾𝑇𝑇4superscript𝐿2𝐾superscript𝜇2subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛subscriptΓ𝑛Non-IIDsubscript⏟3𝐿2𝜇subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇subscript𝜌𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑁subscriptΓ𝑛Biased Selection\displaystyle\underbrace{\frac{1}{(\gamma+T)T}\frac{4L^{2}}{K\mu^{2}}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}\Gamma_{n}}_{\textit{Non-IID}}+\underbrace{\frac{3L}{2\mu}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}(\frac{T_{n}}{KT}-\frac{\rho_{min}}{N})\Gamma_{n}}_{\textit{Biased Selection}}
+\displaystyle+ 1(γ+T)​T​4​L​ΛK2​μ2​∑n∈𝒩Tnz+1​Φn⏟Noise Influence,subscript⏟1𝛾𝑇𝑇4𝐿Λsuperscript𝐾2superscript𝜇2subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1subscriptΦ𝑛Noise Influence\displaystyle\underbrace{\frac{1}{(\gamma+T)T}\frac{4L\Lambda}{K^{2}\mu^{2}}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}^{z+1}\Phi_{n}}_{\textit{Noise Influence}}, (4)

where Λ=4​ΞG2​d​c22Λ4superscriptsubscriptΞ𝐺2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑐22\Lambda=4\Xi_{G}^{2}dc_{2}^{2}, z=1𝑧1z=1, Φn=ln⁡(1/δn)Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1subscript𝛿𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{n})}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for GM and Λ=8​d​ΞL2Λ8𝑑superscriptsubscriptΞ𝐿2\Lambda=8d\Xi_{L}^{2}, z=2𝑧2z=2, Φn=1Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{1}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for LM.

Briefly speaking, Theorem 5 is proved by including the quantified influence of the biased client selection (which can be derived based on ρm​i​nsubscript𝜌𝑚𝑖𝑛\rho_{min}) and the influence of DP noises (defined in Lemmas 1 and 2) into convergence rate analysis. The detailed proof is presented in Appendix B. Through the convergence analysis, we have the following insights:

  • •

    The client selection probability TnK​Tsubscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇\frac{T_{n}}{KT} appears in three terms: non-IID, biased selection and noise influence in the convergence rate. If the noise influence is omitted, an unbiased selection with Tn=K​TNsubscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇𝑁T_{n}=\frac{KT}{N} makes ρm​i​n=1subscript𝜌𝑚𝑖𝑛1\rho_{min}=1 vanishing the biased selection term. This is a special scenario in our study. Due to the existence of the noise influence term, a uniform selection with Tn=K​TNsubscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇𝑁T_{n}=\frac{KT}{N} cannot guarantee a small value of the noise influence term.

  • •

    If the data distribution among clients is IID implying that Γn=0subscriptΓ𝑛0\Gamma_{n}=0, both the non-IID and biased selection terms vanish. We only need to minimize noise influence by tuning Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} to achieve the highest model utility. In distributed machine learning, it is possible to make the data distribution on workers IID [29], which can significantly simplify the client selection problem with heterogeneous privacy. However, this problem is very complicated in FL because IID data distribution cannot be achieved [24] and we need to consider both the noise influence and the data distribution to maximize model utility.

IV Optimizing Client Selection

In this section, we formulate the client selection problem in Sec. IV-A. Then, we explore how to solve the problem in practical systems in Sec. IV-B. More discussion about our solution is represented in Sec. IV-C.

IV-A Optimizing Convergence Rate

Given an arbitrary selection strategy (defined by Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}), Theorem 5 proves the upper bound of the gap between the expected global loss and the optimal global loss after T𝑇T global iterations. Thus, it is easy to formulate the problem to maximize the model utility of DPFL after T𝑇T global iterations, equivalent to minimizing the upper bound defined in Eq. (5). Here Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} can be regarded as variables to be optimized.

To focus on optimizing Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}, we ignore all terms without Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} in the upper bound. Then, we formulate the problem to minimize this upper bound after T𝑇T global iterations. For simplicity, we regard all parameters not related to Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} as constants by letting ΩA=1(γ+T)​T​4​L​ΛK2​μ2subscriptΩ𝐴1𝛾𝑇𝑇4𝐿Λsuperscript𝐾2superscript𝜇2\Omega_{A}=\frac{1}{(\gamma+T)T}\frac{4L\Lambda}{K^{2}\mu^{2}} and ΩB=1(γ+T)​T​4​L2K​μ2+1T​3​L2​K​μsubscriptΩ𝐵1𝛾𝑇𝑇4superscript𝐿2𝐾superscript𝜇21𝑇3𝐿2𝐾𝜇\Omega_{B}=\frac{1}{(\gamma+T)T}\frac{4L^{2}}{K\mu^{2}}+\frac{1}{T}\frac{3L}{2K\mu}. Then the objective function to optimize client selection is 𝒥​(T1,⋯,TN)=ΩA​∑n∈𝒩Tnz+1​Φn+ΩB​∑n∈𝒩Tn​Γn𝒥subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁subscriptΩ𝐴subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1subscriptΦ𝑛subscriptΩ𝐵subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛subscriptΓ𝑛\mathcal{J}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N})=\Omega_{A}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}^{z+1}\Phi_{n}+\Omega_{B}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}\Gamma_{n}, and the problem becomes:

ℙ1:minT1,⋯,TN⁡𝒥​(T1,⋯,TN):subscriptℙ1subscriptsubscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁𝒥subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{1}:\min_{T_{1},\cdots,T_{N}}\mathcal{J}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N})
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. ∑n∈𝒩Tn=K​T,Tn∈ℕ,∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇formulae-sequencesubscript𝑇𝑛ℕfor-all𝑛𝒩\displaystyle\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}=KT,\quad T_{n}\in\mathbb{N},\forall n\in\mathcal{N},

where z=1𝑧1z=1, Φn=ln⁡(1/δn)Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1subscript𝛿𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{n})}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for the Gaussian mechanism and z=2𝑧2z=2, Φn=1Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{1}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for the Laplace mechanism.

IV-B Solution

If we relax the constraint by letting Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} be a non-negative real number, it is easy to prove that 𝒥​(⋅)𝒥⋅\mathcal{J}(\cdot) is a convex function.

Theorem 6.

𝒥​(T1,⋯,TN)𝒥subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁\mathcal{J}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N}) is a convex function with respect to Tn,∀n∈𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, under either GM or LM.

The proof of Theorem 6 is immediate since the Hessian Matrix of function 𝒥​(⋅)𝒥⋅\mathcal{J}(\cdot) is a semi positive-definite matrix. The detailed proof is presented in Appendix C.

However, solving ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} is non-trivial in practice because we need the knowledge of problem-related parameters such as γ𝛾\gamma, μ𝜇\mu, L𝐿L, and ΓnsubscriptΓ𝑛\Gamma_{n} for exactly solving this problem. In FL, the PS does not have the knowledge of these parameters prior to model training. In view of this challange, we propose two solutions to solve ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1}: approximately optimizing Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} by ignoring ΓnsubscriptΓ𝑛\Gamma_{n} and exactly optimizing Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} with estimated problem-related parameters. Both solutions are needed because the approximate solution can be derived without the knowledge of problem-related parameters, which can be used by the PS before the accurate solution is derived.

IV-B1 Approximate Solution

Based on our convergence analysis, if Γn=0,∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesubscriptΓ𝑛0for-all𝑛𝒩\Gamma_{n}=0,\forall n\in\mathcal{N} (implying the data distribution is IID), it becomes easy to solve ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} without the necessity to estimate problem-related parameters. The sequence of Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} derived in this case is an approximate solution of ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1}, which can be denoted as follows.

Proposition 1.

If Γn=0,∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesubscriptΓ𝑛0for-all𝑛𝒩\Gamma_{n}=0,\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, the solution to minimize 𝒥​(⋅)𝒥⋅\mathcal{J}(\cdot) in ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} is Tn,0∗=K​T∑n′∈𝒩(ΦnΦn′)1z,∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛0𝐾𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝒩superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑛subscriptΦsuperscript𝑛′1𝑧for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n,0}^{*}=\frac{KT}{\sum_{n^{\prime}\in\mathcal{N}}(\frac{\Phi_{n}}{\Phi_{n^{\prime}}})^{\frac{1}{z}}},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, where z=1𝑧1z=1, Φn=ln⁡(1/δn)Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1subscript𝛿𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{n})}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for GM and z=2𝑧2z=2, Φn=1Dn2​ϵn2subscriptΦ𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑛2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛2\Phi_{n}=\frac{1}{D_{n}^{2}\epsilon_{n}^{2}} for LM.

The solution in Proposition 1 is calculated by using Lagrange Multiplier, with details provided in Appendix D.

    It is easy to prove that the objective function in ℙ2subscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}_{2} is convex with respect to each individual variable. Thus, ℙ2subscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}_{2} can be efficiently solved by alternatively optimizating each variable.

With the estimation of problem-related parameters, it is easy to solve ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} to get the optimal Tn∗superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}^{*} for the second stage. Note that the remaining total number of global iterations is T−T0𝑇subscript𝑇0T-T_{0}. Therefore, the optimal selection probability for client n𝑛n is pn∗=Tn∗K​(T−T0)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇subscript𝑇0p_{n}^{*}=\frac{T_{n}^{*}}{K(T-T_{0})}. Based on the two-stage design, the entire algorithm framework of DPFL-BCS for PS and clients are presented in Alg. 1 and Alg. 2, respectively.

IV-C Discussion

Computing pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} to optimize client selection is not cost free. We further discuss the cost associated with this process.

Privacy Budget Consumption for Computing pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}. Considering the privacy leakage risks for reporting local loss values for parameter estimation, selected clients generate DP noises to distort local loss value as well. We regard loss values, i.e., ηt​Fn​(𝐰^t−1)subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1\eta_{t}{F}_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1}) and ηt​Fn​(𝐰nt)subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐹𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑛\eta_{t}{F}_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{t}_{n}), as two additional parameters in model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} for disturbance. In other words, the model dimension of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is expanded from d𝑑d to d+2𝑑2d+2 in the first stage.

Because we involve two additional parameters, the sensitivity function should be altered accordingly. Let ΘΘ\Theta denotes the maximum value of the loss function evaluated by a single sample. Then, the additional sensitivity incurred by protecting each local loss value Fn​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰F_{n}(\mathbf{w}) for client n𝑛n can be represented as Δ​Fn=ΘDnΔsubscript𝐹𝑛Θsubscript𝐷𝑛\Delta F_{n}=\frac{\Theta}{D_{n}}. Therefore, in the t𝑡t-th global iteration during the first stage, selected client n∈𝒮t𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡n\in\mathcal{S}_{t} generates DP noises to distort both gradients 𝐠ntsubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡𝑛\mathbf{g}^{t}_{n} and loss values, i.e., ηt​Fn​(𝐰^t−1)subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1\eta_{t}F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1}) and ηt​Fn​(𝐰nt)subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐹𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑛\eta_{t}F_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{t}_{n}), based on the revised sensitivity:

Δ​𝐠n′={2​ηt​ΞG+2​ηt​ΘDn,GM;2​ηt​ΞL+2​ηt​ΘDn,LM.Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛′cases2subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΞ𝐺2subscript𝜂𝑡Θsubscript𝐷𝑛GM;2subscript𝜂𝑡subscriptΞ𝐿2subscript𝜂𝑡Θsubscript𝐷𝑛LM.\displaystyle\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n}^{\prime}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{cl}\frac{2\eta_{t}\Xi_{G}+2\eta_{t}\Theta}{D_{n}},&\text{GM;}\\ \frac{2\eta_{t}\Xi_{L}+2\eta_{t}\Theta}{D_{n}},&\text{LM.}\end{array}\right. (13)

The proof is straightforward by using the sensitivity definition. When considering exposing two additional loss values, the total sensitivity is bounded by Δ​𝐠n′=Δ​𝐠n+2​ηt​Δ​FnΔsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑛′Δsubscript𝐠𝑛2subscript𝜂𝑡Δsubscript𝐹𝑛\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n}^{\prime}=\Delta\mathbf{g}_{n}+2\eta_{t}\Delta F_{n}. Then, the selected client n𝑛n uploads the noisy gradients 𝐠^ntsubscriptsuperscript^𝐠𝑡𝑛\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{t}_{n} and noisy loss values, i.e., F^n​(𝐰^t−1)subscript^𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1\hat{F}_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1}) and F^n​(𝐰nt)subscript^𝐹𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑛\hat{F}_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{t}_{n}), to the PS.

Computation and Memory Overhead. All problem-related parameters can be estimated after T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} global iterations. Since both ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} and ℙ2subscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}_{2} are convex optimization problems, it only consumes little computational resource. Besides, T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} is a small constant as we only need T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} samples to reasonably estimate these parameters. It implies that the memory overhead is O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(N) on the PS side because the PS only spends O​(1)𝑂1O(1) memory overhead for each client.

Incomplete Information with Privacy Budget. In our study, we suppose that each client honestly reports its privacy budget to the PS, which is the same as scenarios studied by most related works such as [8]. Nonetheless, it is possible that clients refuse to report their privacy budget information in practice [30]. Based on recent studies, we briefly discuss how DPFL-BCS can overcome this deficiency.

In DPFL-BCS, it is possible to add a module to infer the privacy budgets of clients on the PS. The PS can obtain the distribution of privacy budgets among clients by making a survey questionnaire [30]. Furthermore, the PS can infer the privacy budgets of clients from their historical training information [15].

V Performance Evaluation

In this section, we report our experimental results conducted with real datasets and compared with the SOTA baselines.

V-A Experimental Settings

Datasets. We conduct experiments on five popular public datasets, i.e., Lending Club [17], MNIST [19], Fashion-MNIST [7], FEMNIST[20] and CIFAR-10 [21].

Lending Club contains nearly 890,000 loan records collected from a peer-to-peer lending platform, which is available on Kaggle. We randomly select 40,000 records for our experiments, with 80% as the training set and 20% as the test set. The further processing of the Lending Club dataset is the same as that in [17]. We set the interest rates of loans per annum as the label of each record while others are used as features. We remove unique identifier features, such as IDs and member IDs. Features with the value of “NULL” are removed as well before we encode categorical features. After that, we employ Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to further select top ten important features as our training features. Finally, we regularize each selected feature, which is conducive to the stability of the training model.

Both MNIST and Fashion-MNIST contain 70,000 28*28 grayscale images which can be classified into 10 classes. The labels of MNIST images are digits from 0-9, while the labels of Fashion-MNIST images are daily goods. The CIFAR-10 dataset consists of 60,000 32*32 color images, which can also be classified into 10 categories. For each dataset, we randomly select 10,000 samples as test set and the rest as training set.

FEMNIST contains 805,263 28*28 grayscale images collected from 3,500 users, which can be classified into 62 classes (10 for digits, 26 for lowercase letters and 26 for uppercase letters). We randomly sample 10% samples from the whole dataset for conducting our experiments. Then, we randomly select 90% samples as training set, and use the rest as test set.

The training set will be further distributed to FL clients as private local datasets. Whereas, the test set is retained by the PS for evaluating model performance.

Trained Models. We implement a linear regression model containing 11 parameters same as the one in [17] to predict the interest rate of the Lending Club records. The loss function is defined by Mean Square Error (MSE) for Lending Club while by Cross-Entropy for other four datasets. We implement a convolutional neural network (CNN) model with two convolution layers and a fully connected layer [7] to classify MNIST images. The model consists of 4,266 parameters. The LeNet-5 network [7] is implemented to classify Fashion-MNIST images which contains 61,706 parameters.

We implement a CNN model similar to the one in [20] with 67,026 parameters to classify FEMNIST images, which contains two convolution layers and three fully connected layers. Each convolution layer is followed by a BatchNorm2d layer, a ReLU function and a max pooling layer. The ResNet-20 [21] is implemented to classify CIFAR-10 images, which contains 272,474 parameters.

System Settings. We simulate a FL system with a single PS and N=100𝑁100N=100 clients. We set the total number of global iterations as T=200𝑇200T=200, while the parameter estimation phase lasts T0=10subscript𝑇010T_{0}=10 iterations. In each iteration, the PS selects K=20𝐾20K=20 participating clients to conduct local training. For all five models, each client adopts the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) for local training with the momentum 0.90.90.9 and the weight decay rate 2×10−42superscript1042\times 10^{-4} [19]. We set learning rates as 0.021+t2000.021𝑡200\frac{0.02}{1+\frac{t}{200}}, 0.051+t2000.051𝑡200\frac{0.05}{1+\frac{t}{200}}, 0.051+t2000.051𝑡200\frac{0.05}{1+\frac{t}{200}}, 0.051+t2000.051𝑡200\frac{0.05}{1+\frac{t}{200}} and 0.21+t1000.21𝑡100\frac{0.2}{1+\frac{t}{100}} for Lending Club, MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 [11].

We implement Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms to generate noises to obfuscate model gradients and local loss values in our experiments. According to prior works [16, 7], the gradients should be clipped to bound sensitivity before adding DP noises. We use the norm clipping for gradients to obtain the bound ΞGsubscriptΞ𝐺\Xi_{G} and ΞLsubscriptΞ𝐿\Xi_{L} for Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms, respectively. Let B𝐵B denotes the clipping bound. Each gradient is clipped by ∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)​[j]=∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)​[j]max⁡(1,‖∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)‖2/B)∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁delimited-[]𝑗∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁delimited-[]𝑗1subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁2𝐵\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)[j]=\frac{\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)[j]}{\max(1,\|\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)\|_{2}/B)} and ∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)​[j]=∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)​[j]max⁡(1,‖∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)‖1/B)∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁delimited-[]𝑗∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁delimited-[]𝑗1subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁1𝐵\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)[j]=\frac{\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)[j]}{\max(1,\|\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)\|_{1}/B)} for Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms. Here, ζ∈𝒟n𝜁subscript𝒟𝑛\zeta\in\mathcal{D}_{n} is a data sample and ∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)​[j]∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁delimited-[]𝑗\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta)[j] is the j𝑗j-th item of the vector ∇Fn​(𝐰^t−1,ζ)∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript^𝐰𝑡1𝜁\nabla F_{n}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{t-1},\zeta). Through trials of different values, we finally set B=150,20,25,25𝐵150202525B=150,20,25,25 and 555 for the Lending Club, MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10. Besides, we also need to set a proper value for the maximum value of the loss function, i.e., ΘΘ\Theta, according to our design. This is a limited number in most machine learning problems. For example, for a classification problem with 10 labels, we can use a random guess strategy to estimate the upper bound of loss values. If the loss is defined by the Cross-Entropy function, the loss of the random guess strategy (which is regarded as the worst strategy achieving the highest loss value) is Θ=ln⁡10Θ10\Theta=\ln{10}. For the linear regression model predicting interest rate with Lending Club, we cap Θ=150Θ150\Theta=150 according to our experiment results.

To conduct experiments under non-IID data distribution, a well-known property of FL, we allocate training data samples to clients according to the Dirichlet distribution [31], in which a parameter α𝛼\alpha can control the non-IID degree of data distribution on clients. A smaller α𝛼\alpha implies a more significant non-IID degree and vice verse.

The privacy requirements are heterogeneous, and each client uses a uniform and random method to set its privacy budget ϵnsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛\epsilon_{n} and δnsubscript𝛿𝑛\delta_{n} from the ranges [ϵm​i​n,ϵm​a​x]subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑖𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥[\epsilon_{min},\epsilon_{max}] and [δm​i​n,δm​a​x]subscript𝛿𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝛿𝑚𝑎𝑥[\delta_{min},\delta_{max}], respectively. Note that δm​i​n=δm​a​x=0subscript𝛿𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝛿𝑚𝑎𝑥0\delta_{min}=\delta_{max}=0 for the Laplace mechanism. By default, we set δm​i​n=10−5subscript𝛿𝑚𝑖𝑛superscript105\delta_{min}=10^{-5} and δm​a​x=10−4subscript𝛿𝑚𝑎𝑥superscript104\delta_{max}=10^{-4} for the Gaussian mechanism. We set ϵm​i​n=0.1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑖𝑛0.1\epsilon_{min}=0.1 for Lending Club and MNIST, ϵm​i​n=0.5subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑖𝑛0.5\epsilon_{min}=0.5 for Fashion-MNIST and FEMNIST, and ϵm​i​n=1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑖𝑛1\epsilon_{min}=1 for CIFAR-10. We vary the degree of privacy heterogeneity by changing ϵm​a​xsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥\epsilon_{max}.

Baselines. We implement three kinds of baselines:

  • •

    FedSGD [32] does not involve any DP mechanism to protect exposed gradients. It provides the upper bound of model utility to measure the influence of DP noises on FL performance.

  • •

    DPSGD [16] and DMLDP [17] adopt Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms to protect gradients, respectively. However, they fail to consider privacy heterogeneity among different clients, and select all clients with the same probability.

  • •

    WeiAvg was proposed in [8] to handle privacy heterogeneity by heuristically adjusting the aggregation weight of each client based on its privacy budget. PFA is upgraded from WeiAvg, relying on extracted top singular subspace of model gradients. Its computation overhead is prohibitive, and cannot run at all for ResNet-20 with 272,474 parameters.

  • •

    PRIVATEFL [12] was designed to locally implement a personalized data transformation to mitigate data heterogeneity among clients in DPFL. However, it uniformly selects participating clients because it ignores privacy heterogeneity among clients.

To fairly compare these baselines, we conduct two groups of experiments to compare them based on Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms, respectively. Note that DPFL-BCS is a generic framework that can incorporate both Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms. For a given DP mechanism, we fix the privacy budget consumed by each algorithm to compare their model utility in terms of MSE for Lending Club and model classification accuracy for other datasets.

V-B Experimental Results

V-B1 Comparison of Model Utility under Fixed Privacy Heterogeneity

We compare model utility of different algorithms under fixed privacy heterogeneity. More specifically, we set α=3𝛼3\alpha=3 and ϵm​a​x=3subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥3\epsilon_{max}=3 for Lending Club and MNIST, α=3𝛼3\alpha=3 and ϵm​a​x=4subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥4\epsilon_{max}=4 for Fashion-MNIST and FEMNIST, and α=3𝛼3\alpha=3 and ϵm​a​x=6subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥6\epsilon_{max}=6 for CIFAR-10 to allocate the local dataset and sample the privacy budget for each client. The privacy budget is then fixed when comparing different algorithms. The training results are plotted in Fig. 2 with upper subfigures showing results with Gaussian mechanism and lower subfigures showing results with Laplace mechanism. In each figure, the x-axis represents the number of conducted global iterations while the y-axis represents the model utility evaluated by the test set retained by the PS. From these results, we can observe that: 1) DPFL-BCS achieves the highest model utility compared with other DP based FL algorithms. Its performance is the one closest to FedSGD which does not involve DP noises to protect gradients; 2) Compared to Gaussian mechanism, Laplace mechanism compromises model utility more significantly, which however can provide a stronger privacy protection; 3) Although our theoretical analysis is based on convex loss, experimental results indicate that DPFL-BCS is effective under both convex and non-convex loss functions; 4) PFA and WeiAvg outperform DPSGD and DMLDP because they have considered privacy heterogeneity in their design. Yet, their performance is still much worse than ours because they are heuristic based; 5) PRIVATEFL outperforms DPSGD with Gaussian noises because it can reduce data heterogeneity among clients to improve the utility. However, PRIVATEFL fails to improve the performance of DMLDP with Laplace noises, and even achieves worse performance on CIFAR-10. Besides, its performance is always worse than ours in each experimental case because it does not take privacy heterogeneity into account.

V-B2 Visualizing Selection Decisions for Heterogeneous Privacy

To better understand the biased decisions made by DPFL-BCS, we visualize a particular experiment case conducted with MNIST plus the Gaussian mechanism while the results of other nine cases are shown in Appendix E due to limited space. Here, we only visualize the estimation of ΓnsubscriptΓ𝑛{\Gamma}_{n} in Fig. 3(a) after the first stage, which can be used to explain how DPFL-BCS makes biased client selection decisions. With the estimation of ΓnsubscriptΓ𝑛\Gamma_{n}, we can solve problem ℙ2subscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}_{2} to obtain the estimation of γ𝛾\gamma, L𝐿L and μ𝜇\mu, which are shown in Appendix E.

Based on estimated problem-related parameters, we finally optimize Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} by solving ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} to obtain the optimal client selection decision, i.e., Tn∗,∀n∈𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n}^{*},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}. As we observe from Fig. 3(b), the optimal client selection decision is indeed biased to accommodate heterogeneous privacy budget distribution and data distribution. The results of other experiment cases are very similar with details presented in Appendix E.

V-B3 Combination with DP-Improving Algorithms

We demonstrate that it is possible to combine DPFL-BCS with other DP-improving algorithms, which have ignored clients’ heterogeneous privacy requirement. We implement PRIVATEFL [12] as a case study under both Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms. It means that a biased client selection strategy in lieu of a pure random strategy is adopted in PRIVATEFL. The results in Table I are presented with mean ±plus-or-minus\pm std, which show that: 1) PRIVATEFL has poor performance under heterogeneous privacy settings because it does not discriminate clients with heterogeneous privacy when making selection decisions; 2) DPFL-BCS can significantly improve the performance of PRIVATEFL under heterogeneous privacy by selecting clients in a biased manner.

V-B4 Comparison of Model Utility by Varying Privacy Heterogeneity

To validate that DPFL-BCS can adapt with the degree of privacy heterogeneity, we vary ϵm​a​xsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥\epsilon_{max} from 222 to 101010 for CIFAR-10, while from 111 to 666 for other four datasets to examine how the degree of privacy heterogeneity influences model utility. The results presented by mean ±plus-or-minus\pm std are plotted in Fig. 4 with the x-axis representing the privacy heterogeneity degree and the y-axis representing the final model utility.

From the experimental results, we can observe that: 1) Under all experiment cases with different levels of privacy heterogeneity, DPFL-BCS is always the best one which can achieve the highest model utility compared with other DP based baselines; 2) As the increase of the privacy budget upper bound ϵm​a​xsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥\epsilon_{max}, model utility of DPFL-BCS, WeiAvg and PFA gets better as these algorithms can exploit privacy heterogeneity to improve FL performance. However, PRIVATEFL, DPSGD and DMLDP algorithms cannot effectively improve FL performance with the increase of ϵm​a​xsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑎𝑥\epsilon_{max} because the privacy heterogeneity issue is ignored in their design.

V-B5 Comparison of Model Utility by Varying Data Heterogeneity

To further explore how the heterogeneity degree of data distribution influences the model utility, we conduct experiments by varying the parameter α𝛼\alpha of the Dirichlet distribution from 0.50.50.5 to 888. Then, we compare the final model utility after T=200𝑇200T=200 iterations between DPFL-BCS and other baselines. The experimental results with mean ±plus-or-minus\pm std are presented in Fig. 5 with the x-axis representing the non-IID degree and the y-axis representing the final model utility.

As we can see from these results: 1) In Dirichlet distribution, a smaller α𝛼\alpha implies more significant non-IID. Thus, the model utility deteriorates with the decrease of α𝛼\alpha; 2) DPFL-BCS is always the best one achieving the highest model utility among all DP baselines. The reason is that DPFL-BCS can properly balance data and privacy heterogeneity to significantly improve model utility. In particular, it is worth noting that DPFL-BCS can notably improve 30∼similar-to\sim40% model accuracy when α𝛼\alpha is extremely small; 3) WeiAvg and PFA can only work well when α𝛼\alpha is not very small because their heuristic design fails to optimize model utility in extreme cases.

VI Related Work

In this section, we briefly overview the development of FL and its security threats. Then, we highlight our contributions in light of recent advances in DPFL.

VI-A Federated Learning and Security Threats

The FL framework was originally proposed to protect data privacy when training machine learning models [3]. [32] is the first one devising model average algorithms, i.e., FedAvg and FedSGD, for FL, which allows decentralized clients to only exchange model parameters (or gradients) with the PS to complete model training. The data privacy is preserved since clients never expose their raw data to the PS. Later on, [24] analyzed the convergence of FedAvg/FedSGD under non-IID data distribution. To accelerate the convergence of FL, different variants of FedAvg/FedSGD have been proposed by [33, 28] with theoretical guarantees.

Owing to its privacy protection capability, FL has been widely used in privacy sensitive applications, such as digital health [34] and smart cities [35]. Nevertheless, as reported in [4], FL is still susceptible to two kinds of malicious attacks: model performance attacks and data privacy attacks. The objective of model performance attacks is to demolish FL training to yield a final model with poor performance. For example, a data poisoning attack was proposed in [20] that can attack FL by flipping data labels on clients. Then, a more advanced attack algorithm was designed by using gradient ascent to fine-tune the global model and increase its loss on unseen data. Our study focuses on the second kind of attacks which attempt to infer data privacy from leaked model information. In [5], a white-box inference attack was developed that processes extracted gradient features from different layers of the target model separately, and combines their information to compute the membership probability of a target data point. Zhu et al. [23] proposed the DLG (Deep Leakage from Gradients) algorithm, which can reconstruct original samples with high accuracy using leaked gradients.

VI-B Differentially Private Federated Learning

In order to defend against data privacy attacks targeting for model gradients in machine learning (ML), DP mechanisms were introduced, which distort private information with zero-mean random noises. Wu et al. [17] incorporated Laplace mechanism into distributed ML to protect the exposed gradients. Nonetheless, its model utility was severely compromised by DP noises since noises are straightly injected. Abadi et al. [16] refined Gaussian mechanism used in ML by more precisely estimating the privacy loss to reduce the scale of random noises. However, these works were not designed for FL, and thus did not consider non-IID data distribution.

Later on, the adoption of DP mechanisms has been extended for DPFL, and efforts were made to alleviate the noise influence on model utility. Huang et al. [9] proposed a novel DPFL framework to adaptively allocate noises injected into gradients. Hu et al. [36] applied the zCDP mechanisms for DPFL to add fewer noises compared to DP mechanisms. Considering that the noise scale is proportional to the exposed model size, compressive sensing [10] and privately gradient selection [7] techniques were introduced into DPFL by reducing the number of exposed parameters. Zhou et al. [11] proposed to optimize the numbers of model exposure times to reduce the influence of DP noises. The work [37] incorporated DP into the popular SCAFFOLD algorithm, which is a variant of FedSGD, by taking data heterogeneity into account. Furthermore, PRIVATEFL[12] was proposed to reduce the client heterogeneity introduced by both data and DP noises through a carefully designed personalized transformation.

However, aforementioned works did not consider privacy heterogeneity among DPFL clients. In reality, DPFL clients set privacy budgets based their own privacy requirement, and thereby the discrepancy of noise scales between different clients is probably significant. Aldaghri et al.[14] proposed a heterogeneous setup for privacy and theoretically analyzed the privacy-utility trade-off in federated linear regression. Then, Liu et al. [8] proposed the WeiAvg algorithm that uses the ratio of privacy as aggregate weights to mitigate the influence from clients with large noises, but this heuristic design failed to optimize model utility. Based on WeiAvg, the PFA algorithm was proposed which divides selected clients into two sets: “public” and “private” in each global iteration based on their privacy budgets. Then, it extracts the top singular subspace of model updates submitted by “public” clients to project model updates of “private” clients before aggregating them with the ratio of privacy. The computational complexity of PFA is prohibitive in practice, proportional to model dimension and client population. Its memory overhead is also significant proportional to the square of model dimension. In contrast, our design is based on convergence analysis, in which the client selection problem under heterogeneous privacy is formulated into a convex optimization problem. Thus, our design is lightweight and guarantees optimized model utility in comparison to PFA.

VII Conclusion

Federated learning is the most popular technique for data privacy preservation in model training. Differentially private has been widely incorporated into FL to enhance the protection level. Nevertheless, the heterogeneous privacy requirement on FL clients will compromise their data values to different extents, which has not been well addressed by existing works. To fill in this gap, we analyze the convergence of FL with DP noises to quantify the influence of DP noises on model utility. Based on convergence analysis, we optimize the client selection strategy that can properly incorporate each client into FL based on its noise scale so that the final model utility is maximized. Moreover, our design is lightweight incurring negligible overhead. Comprehensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate that our design can significantly improve model utility compared with the state-of-the-art baselines. Although our initial work proves the effectiveness of DPFL-BCS, in the future work, we will explore how to extend our design under more complicated scenarios such as online FL and decentralized FL systems.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 5

Proof.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 6

Proof.

It is easy to obtain the Hessian Matrix of the objective function 𝒥​(T1,⋯,TN)=ΩA​∑n∈𝒩Tnz+1​Φn+ΩB​∑n∈𝒩Tn​Γn𝒥subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁subscriptΩ𝐴subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1subscriptΦ𝑛subscriptΩ𝐵subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛subscriptΓ𝑛\mathcal{J}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N})=\Omega_{A}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}^{z+1}\Phi_{n}+\Omega_{B}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}\Gamma_{n} by performing second-order partial derivatives with respect to Tn,∀n∈𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}. Obviously, the matrix is a diagonal matrix because ∂2𝒥∂Tn​∂Tn′=0superscript2𝒥subscript𝑇𝑛subscript𝑇superscript𝑛′0\frac{\partial^{2}\mathcal{J}}{\partial T_{n}\partial T_{n^{\prime}}}=0 if n≠n′𝑛superscript𝑛′n\neq n^{\prime}. In the matrix, diagonal elements, i.e., ∂2𝒥∂Tn2=(z+1)​z​ΩA​Φn​Tnz−1superscript2𝒥superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛2𝑧1𝑧subscriptΩ𝐴subscriptΦ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1\frac{\partial^{2}\mathcal{J}}{\partial T_{n}^{2}}=(z+1)z\Omega_{A}\Phi_{n}T_{n}^{z-1} (z=1𝑧1z=1 for Gaussian mechanism and z=2𝑧2z=2 for Laplace mechanism), are greater than or equal to 0. It means that all its eigenvalues are greater than or equal to 0. Therefore, it is easy to prove that the matrix is a semi positive-definite matrix, and hence 𝒥​(⋅)𝒥⋅\mathcal{J}(\cdot) is a convex function with respect to Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}. ∎

Appendix D Proof of Proposition 1

Proof.

With Γn=0,∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesubscriptΓ𝑛0for-all𝑛𝒩\Gamma_{n}=0,\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, the objective function in ℙ1subscriptℙ1\mathbb{P}_{1} can be simplified as 𝒥′​(T1,⋯,TN)=∑n∈𝒩Tnz+1​Φnsuperscript𝒥′subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1subscriptΦ𝑛\mathcal{J}^{\prime}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N})=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}^{z+1}\Phi_{n}. If we relax the constraint by letting Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} be a non-negative real number, it is easy to prove that 𝒥′​(T1,⋯,TN)superscript𝒥′subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁\mathcal{J}^{\prime}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N}) is also a convex objective function with respect to Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} with both the Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms. Therefore, we can obtain the optimal analytical solution to minimize 𝒥′​(⋅)superscript𝒥′⋅\mathcal{J}^{\prime}(\cdot) by using Lagrange Multiplier. By introducing a lagrange multiplier λ𝜆\lambda, the equality constraint, ∑n∈𝒩Tn=K​Tsubscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}=KT, can be transformed into a part of the new objective function, represented as 𝒥′′​(T1,⋯,TN,λ)=∑n∈𝒩Tnz+1​Φn+λ​(∑n∈𝒩Tn−K​T)superscript𝒥′′subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑁𝜆subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1subscriptΦ𝑛𝜆subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}(T_{1},\cdots,T_{N},\lambda)=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}^{z+1}\Phi_{n}+\lambda(\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}-KT).

Then, we can get the partial derivative of 𝒥′′​(⋅)superscript𝒥′′⋅\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}(\cdot) with respect to Tn,∀n∈𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, which is represented as ∂𝒥′′∂Tn=(z+1)​Tnz​Φn+λsuperscript𝒥′′subscript𝑇𝑛𝑧1superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑧subscriptΦ𝑛𝜆\frac{\partial\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}}{\partial T_{n}}=(z+1)T_{n}^{z}\Phi_{n}+\lambda, and with respect to λ𝜆\lambda, which is represented as ∂𝒥′′∂λ=∑n∈𝒩Tn−K​Tsuperscript𝒥′′𝜆subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑛𝐾𝑇\frac{\partial\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}}{\partial\lambda}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}T_{n}-KT. Finally, we can obtain the optimal solution, Tn,0∗,∀n∈𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛0for-all𝑛𝒩T_{n,0}^{*},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, to minimize 𝒥′′​(⋅)superscript𝒥′′⋅\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}(\cdot), which satisfies ∂𝒥′′∂Tn,0∗=0,∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒥′′superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛00for-all𝑛𝒩\frac{\partial\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}}{\partial T_{n,0}^{*}}=0,\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, and ∂𝒥′′∂λ=0superscript𝒥′′𝜆0\frac{\partial\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}}{\partial\lambda}=0.

With ∂𝒥′′∂Tn,0∗=0,∀n∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒥′′superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛00for-all𝑛𝒩\frac{\partial\mathcal{J}^{\prime\prime}}{\partial T_{n,0}^{*}}=0,\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, for any client i𝑖i and j𝑗j (i,j∈𝒩𝑖𝑗𝒩i,j\in\mathcal{N}), we have Ti,0∗=(ΦjΦi)(1z)​Tj,0∗superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖0superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑗subscriptΦ𝑖1𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑗0T_{i,0}^{*}=(\frac{\Phi_{j}}{\Phi_{i}})^{(\frac{1}{z})}T_{j,0}^{*}.
